query: How do Carolina Core Overlay courses work?
response: Carolina Core Overlay courses allow students to apply the methods of one learning outcome from a Carolina Core course to another Carolina Core course in a different discipline. This way, students can deepen their understanding of a particular concept by seeing it from multiple perspectives. When choosing an overlay course, consider selecting one that naturally aligns with the learning outcome you want to reinforce. It is important to note that no more than two overlays are allowed, and they should be chosen carefully to maximize the benefits of interdisciplinary learning. Also, keep in mind that the total Carolina Core credit hours must add up to a minimum of 31 hours.

Cross-listed courses may have different course delivery and location.

query: What are the requirements for a syllabus?
response: The requirements for a syllabus generally include providing essential information about the course such as the course title, course number, semester/year, class location, instructor's name, office location, office hours, e-mail address, office phone number, and TA information (if needed). Furthermore, the course description, goals, and learning outcomes should be specified. The goals and learning outcomes should be SMART, meaning specific, measurable, agreed upon, realistic, and time-framed. At least three to five learning outcomes should be listed, including at least one from a given list by the DPA committee. Additionally, the overall structure of the course, course requirements, and course policies need to be outlined. These sections detail what students will have to do in the course, including assignments, exams, projects, and performances. The nature and format of these assignments should be described. Expectations and procedures concerning attendance, tardiness, class participation, missed exams or assignments, accommodation for disabilities or special needs, and academic honesty should be stated. Lastly, assessment and grading procedures should align with the learning outcomes and should include various methods of evaluation.

ground_truth: "A cognate is series of courses that display a distinct curricular pattern in one or more disciplines different from the major. Undergraduate cognates require a minimum of 12 credit hours in advanced level courses related to,but outside the major. Graduate cognates range between 9 and 18 credit hours. Cognates are variable according to what is appropriate as determined by the student and the major advisor. Thus,cognates are not subject to faculty governance review,and do not appear on either the transcripts or the diplomas." (ACAF 2.00)

query: What is a concentration?
response: A concentration is a specialized program of study within a larger field or major. It allows students to focus on a specific area of interest and develop expertise in that area. In this case, the Concentration in Performance is offered by the Department of Theatre and Dance at the University of South Carolina. It is a specialized program of study that prepares students for a career in theatre. By choosing this concentration, students will appear on their official transcript as "Concentration in Performance," indicating their focus on theatre studies. The features of the Performance Concentration include fundamentals of acting onstage and for the camera, voice, physical acting, and ensemble devising. Students will also have the opportunity to audit for all productions and collaborate with MFA acting students. Additionally, the concentration recognizes students' efforts in our production program with a special notation on their official transcript.

query: What is an integrative course?
response: An integrative course is a type of course that combines both theoretical instruction and practical application. It goes beyond traditional lectures by engaging students in discussions, reflections, and exercises that prompt them to integrate their knowledge into real-world scenarios. This approach not only deepens their understanding of the material but also prepares them for future applications of their learning. The goal of an integrative course is to create a holistic learning environment where students can engage in activities beyond the classroom and make connections between these experiences. It is designed to bring together faculty, instructors, and graduate students interested in exploring ways to help students reflect on and connect what they do within and beyond their curriculum, embrace multiple perspectives, and synthesize and transfer their knowledge to new, complex situations. The objective is to obtain a deeper understanding of the ideals of integrative and experiential learning and develop a toolbox of simple techniques to engage students in reflection on their experiences within and beyond the classroom.

ground_truth: DegreeWorks is the University’s degree audit system. DegreeWorks aids both students and advisors in monitoring students’ progress toward degree and assist students in choosing the most appropriate courses to fulfill degree requirements. Integrated with students’ academic records in Banner,DegreeWorks matches student record data (courses,hours grades) with degree requirements categorically to identify which courses meet degree requirements and which courses need to be completed. Degree works also allows users to run “what if” and “look ahead” scenarios to both show how project courses will apply to a student’s major and apply a student’s course history to another program of study. ( Office of the University Registrar ) Learn more with the DegreeWorks Overview training module. (/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/toolbox/sysaccess/index.php,https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=syUFK9gy56g&feature=youtu.be)

query: What is EAB Navigate?
response: EAB Navigate is an advising software used at the University of South Carolina to manage student information, schedules, success markers, and progression. Advisors utilize it to prioritize outreach to students based on risk levels and success markers. Students can use it to schedule appointments, view their class schedule, and connect with their success team. It is one of the four advising technologies used on the USC Columbia campus.

ground_truth: What is the difference between prerequisites and restrictions? Prerequisites are courses (successfully completed with a minimum grade of D,unless otherwise defined) that identify the skills and knowledge needed before enrollment in certain courses. Restrictions are conditions that limit the enrollment in certain courses to a select group of students. Restrictions may include: students of a certain academic standing students of a certain class standing (junior,senior,etc.) students admitted to a certain college,academic program,degree,minor,or certificate students belonging to a specific student group (Honors,Trio Scholars,etc.) students required to meet with an instructor,director,or obtain department permission. Note: Restrictions referring to students who have completed a specific number of credit hours and students with a certain minimum GPA cannot be enforced in Banner.

query: What is the format for an undergraduate degree program?
response:
An undergraduate degree program typically consists of a series of courses that students take to earn their bachelor's degree. At the University of South Carolina's College of Education, students can choose from various undergraduate programs with different credit hour requirements and course selection guidelines. For example, to earn a Bachelor of Arts or Science and a Master of Teaching degree, students must maintain a minimum overall GPA of 2.75, complete an undergraduate major based on their desired teaching subject, and take a mix of education and subject-specific courses. Additionally, students may need to complete certain prerequisites or additional courses depending on their chosen undergraduate program and content teaching area. It's essential for students to consult with their advisors to ensure they meet all requirements before registering for courses.

In summary, an undergraduate degree program involves completing specific coursework and meeting particular requirements to earn a bachelor's degree. Students should work closely with their advisors to ensure they fulfill all necessary criteria for their chosen program.

query: What is the process for course actions?
response: The process for course actions at the University of South Carolina involves creating new courses or revising existing ones. This requires approval by the department head and college representative, followed by submission through APPS (the online system used for course Actions Office). The proposal or change request must include justification and be approved by the college representative, Faculty Senate, or Graduate Council. Once approved, the Integrative Course designation can be added, which ensures awareness and attention to foundational skills woven throughout the curriculum. The unit head has regulatory oversight over these courses. However, the ultimate authority lies with the faculty senate, which can approve or reject proposals to create, revise, or terminate courses. Proposals for course changes are submitted in APPS. If adding the Carolina Core designation to an existing course, it requires approval from the Unit Head, College Representative, Curricula and Courses Committee, or Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. Similarly, if changing an existing course, it must be approved by the Unit Head, College/School Representative, Curricula, the question of how the process for course actions does not seem to have any relevance to the context of the Provost to ensure that all readings meet the academic expectation of the University.

query: What is the process for program actions?
response: The process for program actions involves submitting a new course proposal or course change proposal in APPS with the Carolina Core information completed. If adding the Carolina Core designation to an existing course, a course change proposal must be submitted in APPS with the Carolina Core information. In the justification section, the following information should be provided: Carolina Core Integrative Course, Major Name, Degree (e.g., ANTH 444, Anthropology, B.S.’) and explain how the Carolina Core Learning Outcomes are integrated into higher level classes in the major. The reason for this is that every student in that major will take at least one integrative course from the Carolina Core.

query: When is a syllabus required for a proposal?
response: When proposing a Special Topics Education course, a syllabus is indeed required for approval. This document should address the specific topic of interest to educators and include academic requirements along with a clear method of evaluation for the final letter grade. It should also specify a minimum of 700 minutes of instruction over one week of study for each credit offered (i.e. a 3-credit course must include a minimum of 2100 minutes of instruction over 3 weeks). However, once the course is finalized and ready to be offered, it should be submitted to the Department Chair for review and approval. This does not imply that the syllabus should not include a normal face-to-face or online class or module for review.

query: When is the new Bulletin published for the upcoming academic year?
response: The new Bulletin is published before the start of each academic year, usually around late June or early July. It contains information about academic programs and regulations, including important dates and deadlines, as well as updates to the academic bulletin. Additionally, it includes the academic calendar for the upcoming year, which outlines key dates such as the start and end of classes, holidays, and other important events. The bulletin also includes policies related to academics and student conduct, so users should consult it regularly to stay informed about any changes or updates.

ground_truth: Under ACAF 2.00: Interdisciplinary or Interprofessional Programs : Each instance in which an interdisciplinary or interprofessional program is created,revised,or terminated requires letters of concurrence from all related academic units. Dual,Joint and Other Collaborative Degree Programs: The proposal requires the approval of the faculty and leadership in both or all collaborating programs,and letters of concurrence from all university units in closely related disciplines. Under ACAF 2.03: Course Actions : If a course action has the potential to impact the curriculum offering of other units or campuses,then the proponent is responsible for procuring concurrence from such units or campuses. Cross-listed course: If one course is new,and the other already exists,the unit introducing the new course shall include a statement of concurrence from the unit with the existing course. If all courses in a cross-listing are existing courses,one of the units shall submit the course action,indicating all other courses with which the course is cross-listed. All other units shall provide to the initiating unit statements of concurrence,indicating all other courses with which the initiated course is cross-listed. Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: Pre-/Co-Requisites : Changes to Pre-/Co-requisites (either their addition or removal) require a letter of concurrence for the department offering the pre-/co-requisite course unless the impacted courses are in the same department as the subject course. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)

ground_truth: Only programs require external approvals (the President,Board of Trustees (BoT),SACS,and CHE notification or approval),as outline in ACAF 2.00: "All new academic programs and program name changes across the entire USC system must be approved by the president. All new academic programs and program name changes across the entire USC system must be approved by the University Board of Trustees." CHE approval is required in the following cases: New degree programs; New academic certificates of any length in a new CIP code; New academic certificates of more than 18 credit hours in a current CIP code; Program revisions of more than 18 credit hours including the addition of one or more program concentrations and CIP code changes; Program revisions of delivery location to off-campus (50% or more of credit hours); Extension of an approved health professions program to additional sites in-state,and Center and institute proposals requesting new or additional state funding. CHE notification is required in the following cases: Program revisions of 18 credit hours or less (undergraduate) or 12 credit hours or less (graduate),including the addition of a single program concentration; New academic certificates of 18 credit hours or less in a current CIP code; Consolidation of concentrations within an existing program; Program name changes; Program four-letter designator changes; Program terminations; Program revisions of delivery method to distance education delivery (50% or more of credit hours); and Center or institute proposals in which state funding is not required. SACSCOC approval is required six months before implementation in the following cases: New programs,including new dual or joint degree programs; Program revisions that increase program length by 10%; New academic certificates of any length in any CIP code; Program terminations; Program revisions of delivery location to off-campus (50% or more of credit hours); and Program revisions of delivery method to distance education delivery (50% or more of credit hours) SACSCOC notification is required six months before implementation in the following cases: Program revisions of delivery location to off-campus (25% to 49% of credit hours); Program name changes. The program percentages must be based on the total number of credits required to earn the degree,not on the number of required credits in the major,minor or course,or the number of contact hours. SACSCOC may also request more information or additional materials such as a prospectus for any action.

query: What does each drop/add/w date mean? Will I still get money back for dropped classes?
response: The phrase 'each drop/add/w date' refers to two different dates: the add/drop deadline and the tuition refund deadline. These deadlines may vary by course, so it's essential to check them individually. Generally, dropping a course after the add/drop deadline but before the tuition refund deadline will result in no grade assignment and potential loss of some or all tuition paid for the course. After the tuition refund deadline, no grade will be assigned for the dropped course. Still, a student might be eligible for a partial tuition refund depending on the course and the timing of the drop. The amount refunded varies and is determined by the University Registrar's webpage on withdrawal(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/registration/withdrawal/index.php), we cannot predict the exact amount of tuition refunded. However, we know that after the tuition refund deadline, no grade will be assigned for the dropped course.

ground_truth: The last day of drop/add is the last day you can drop a class without being assigned a W. While a W doesn't affect your GPA,financial aid and academic progression standards require that you earn a certain number of hours each year. After the W date,you'll earn an F for each course you drop. Talk with your adviser and financial aid counselor before you make changes to your schedule. Refunds are pro-rated according to the Registrar's schedule.

query: What if I fail a class?
response: If you fail a class, it means that you did not meet the minimum requirements to pass the course. It could be due to various reasons such as poor attendance, lack of effort, or misunderstanding of course material. However, it is important to remember that failing a class does not necessarily mean that you are not capable or intelligent; it could simply mean that you struggled with the specific course content. In this situation, consider retaking the class, seeking help from the instructor, or utilizing tutoring services. Remember, every setback is an opportunity to learn and grow.

query: Are dual degree graduates allowed to sit with the college of their choice?
response: Based on my analysis of the provided context, dual degree graduates are indeed allowed to sit with the college of their choice, subject to certain conditions. Specifically, they must meet the admission requirements of both programs, maintain a GPA of at least 3.00, and complete at least 12 credit hours that count toward both undergraduate and graduate degrees. These conditions ensure that the quality and integrity of each degree involved is maintained. Furthermore, the context suggests that dual degree graduates can apply for dual credit through an Accelerated Bachelor’s/Graduate Study Plan, which combines courses from both undergraduate and graduate programs. This plan must be reviewed and approved by the Graduate Council. So, yes, dual degree graduates are allowed to sit with the college of their choice, subject to the aforementioned conditions.

ground_truth: The normal course load is 15-18 credit hours per semester. Any course load above 18 hours is classified as an overload and requires special permission from the Office of Undergraduate Studies. Overloads are only granted to students who have attained an average of 3.0 or better on a minimum of 12 hours taken on a non-pass/fail basis in the previous full semester. You will need to speak with a team member at the Office of Undergraduate Studies for permission to take more than 18 credit hours.

ground_truth: The Pass-Fail program is designed to encourage students to investigate fields outside of their major curriculum in which they have a specific personal interest,without affecting their grade point average. The only grades assigned on courses taken under the Pass-Fail option are S and U; a grade of S indicates satisfactory performance,while a grade of U indicates unsatisfactory progress. A student will only be given credit for courses in which the grade of S is earned. You can elect the pass/fail option on an elective course by completing a Pass/Fail Form[pdf] available from the Office of the Registrar before the date specified in Master Schedule. To obtain the Academic Dean Signature required on the Pass/Fail Form,please visit Flinn Hall. Note: The pass/fail option is NOT available to undergraduate students whose semester or cumulative GPA is less than 2.000. Students are permitted to take no more than eight courses pass/fail during their undergraduate studies.

ground_truth: You may take up to 18 credit hours of courses in transient status provided that: you are in good academic standing the courses are approved in advance by your academic advisor and the Office of Undergraduate Studies,located in Flinn Hall,on a Special Enrollment Request [pdf] (AS 30) the other institution is fully accredited and the course work meets University specifications for transfer credits. Transient work must be passed with a grade of C or higher. All work taken at other institutions is treated as transfer work and is not included in the USC GPA.

ground_truth: If you are a student in the College of Arts and Sciences,you may complete a second major within the College of Arts and Sciences or the School of Music (Bachelor of Arts track only). You must complete all collegiate requirements (including general education courses and special departmental requirements) as well as the major requirements for the second major. In cases where one major is part of a Bachelor of Arts program and the other is part of a Bachelor of Science program,you must designate one as the official degree of record. A second major eliminates the cognate requirement. You may request a second major by completing a Curriculum Change Form at go.sc.edu/CASforms through the Office of Undergraduate Studies.

ground_truth: Whether you are a family member,friend,professor or classmate you can contact the Community Consultation and Intervention Office within Student Health and Well-Being to express your concern about a USC student. Student Health and Well-Being provides counseling and assistance to USC students coping with stress,anxiety,mental illness and a number of other personal conflicts. If there is an emergency,please call 911 or the USC Police at 803-777-4215. Other emergency contacts can be found on the Crisis Resources webpage.
